Dear Ms. Schlaufman:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Claudia Triestram, Area Manager at (616) 552-3662.

ALLEGATION:
Agency has repeatedly refused to use licensed relatives for placement and has
placed youth in multiple other placements. Agency has not notified parents or
lawyers regarding removals and replacements of youth. Agency has also not
complied with offering required parenting time. Agency has also not held required
meetings regarding removal of youth even though there is ample time to do so.
INVESTIGATION:
Child A was placed into foster care by the Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS on
August 30, 2018 into an unrelated foster home. Relative B and Relative C got
licensed for foster care by Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS on May 25, 2017 to care
for Child A. Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS placed Child A with Relative B and
Relative C for one year, from March 15, 2017 to March 15, 2018. Child A was
returned to his mother on March 15, 2018.
On August 30, 2018, Child A came back into care and was placed into unrelated
foster care with Foster Parent 8. On July 10, 2019, Child A was placed into unrelated
foster care with Foster Parent 9. On January 03, 2020, Child A was placed into
unrelated foster care with Foster Parent 10. On May 12, 2020, Child A was placed
into unrelated foster care with Foster Parent 11. On February 16, 2021, Child A was
placed into unrelated foster care with Foster Parent 12.
Relative B and Relative C remained licensed for relative only foster care.
Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS recommended Relative B and Relative C for two
children, male or female, ages 4-12 with any ethnicity. The next foster home study of
Relative A and Relative B recommended one male child, age 2-4, and relative only.
When Child A was replaced into an unrelated foster home on January 03, 2020 the
agency wrote on the change of placement documentation, “(Child A) was not placed
with relatives due to the need for a court hearing to discuss relative placement.”
When Child A was again replaced into unrelated foster homes on May 12, 2020 and
February 16, 2021, the agency wrote on the change of placement documentation,
“No appropriate relatives were identified for placements.”
During these five unrelated foster home placements, the agency had a willing
licensed relative wanting placement that they, the agency, had licensed for relative
care.
An unannounced visit was made to the Crawford County DHHS office on April 28,
2021. Case records were reviewed and DHHS Foster Care Worker 1, DHHS Foster
Care Worker 2, Licensing Worker 6, and Supervisor 3 were interviewed.

DHHS Foster Care Worker 1 said that Child A was placed with a non-related foster
family because Relative B and Relative C sided with the father of Child A and the
father was physically abusive to the mother of Child A. DHHS Foster Care Worker 1
said that when Child A was placed with Relative B and Relative C they let Child A
talk with his father in contradiction of court orders. DHHS Foster Care Worker 1
additionally said that Relative B and Relative C violated confidentiality by forwarding
a text message regarding another one of the agency’s foster children to another of
the agency’s foster parent. DHHS Foster Child Worker 1 said that the mother of
Child A had a drug overdose and Relative A and Relative B did not report this
incident to DHHS.
Relative B was interviewed by telephone on May 22, 2021. He said that they got
licensed for foster care to care for their nephew. Relative B said that Child A was
placed with them from March 15, 2017 to March 15, 2018. Child A was then returned
to his mother’s care. Relative B said they were not contacted when Child A came
back into care on August 30, 2018. Relative B said that the one year placement of
Child A went very smooth. Relative B said there was a special evaluation done by
the agency November of 2018 after Child A was placed in a non-related foster
home.
The special evaluation found rule violation of Foster Home Rule 9505 Confidentiality
(1) Information obtained, and records maintained is kept confidential
It is concluded that (Relative B) and (Relative C) did breach confidentiality.
(Relative C) admitted she shared a text message between herself and another
foster parent with (Parent D). The text message included the names of other
foster children. (Relative B) and (Relative C) had the phone numbers of other
workers along with the foster care/licensing supervisor. None of these workers
received a call from (Relative B) or (Relative C) voicing their concerns over the
placement of (Child A). When this was discussed with (Relative B) and (Relative
C) during the home visit for the annual inspection of their foster home license,
(Relative C) stated she didn't see what she did wrong but would accept the
consequence of having to complete a corrective action plan. (Relative B)
reported he saw how this could be a breach of confidentiality. It is hoped by
completing the requirement of attending a second orientation to the foster home
licensing rules for the CAP, (Relative C) will better understand the significance of
a foster parent maintaining confidentially and what is entailed to maintain that
confidentiality.
Relative B said they wrote a corrective action plan. Relative B said they were never
invited to any Family Team Meetings and were never contacted when Child A was
moved on July 10, 2019 or January 03, 2020 or February 16, 2021.

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with
a relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
ANALYSIS: There was no documentation in the case file to justify not
placing Child A with Relatives B and C. They were licensed and
had provided care for Child A for a year previously.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
Relative B was interviewed by telephone on May 22, 2021. He said the agency had
not been in contact with them “for a year”. Relative B said he was never invited to a
Family Team Meeting. Relative B said the court terminated parental rights on Child
A’s parents on May 5, 2021. Relative B said he hired an attorney to ask the court for
placement and the motion to place Child A with Relative B and Relative C had been
adjourned and they were waiting on the Judge’s ruling.
MiSACWIS documentation was reviewed and Relative B was not invited to any
FTMs.
When interviewed on April 28, 2021 DHHS Foster Care Worker 1 said that Relative
B sided with his brother and she had found the perfect placement for Child A with his
day care provider and she licensed the home and planned to have them adopt Child
A.

APPLICABLE RULE
POLICY FOM FAMILY TEAM MEETING
722-06B, Page 1
The Family Team Meeting (FTM) is an essential component
of MiTEAM, Michigan’s Child Welfare Practice Model. FTMs
serve as the primary forum for safety planning,
collaborative service planning, service identification, and
assessing progress. The FTM represents a child-centered,
family-driven, strength-based, team-guided approach,
designed to engage families in developing plans for the
safety, permanency, and well-being of their children and
family.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may also
include extended family, friends, neighbors, community-
based service providers, community representatives, tribal
representatives, for Indian children, or other professionals
involved with the family.
During the FTM, participants work together to create a plan
for safety, placement, and permanency tailored to the
individual needs of each child. This process provides a
forum to share ideas and opinions and stresses the
importance of the family’s perspective and involvement. In
addition, this process encourages full participation of all
participants, honest communication, and promotes dignity
and respect.
ANALYSIS: The agency failed to follow the above policy by not inviting the
relatives to FTMs when the Youth reentered care. This would
have allowed for input of the relatives in case planning,
visitation, etc.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

IV. RECOMMENDATION
It recommended there been no change in the licensing status of this public, child
placing agency upon the receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan.
